sub_title: PhD candidate at TU Delft with 4 years of engineering experience at Boeing supplier | Forbes 30 under 30
summary: I use my engineering experience from Boeing supplier together with my solid background in aerospace engineering, optics and physics to improve processes, methods, and develop new products. I feel comfortable working in an eclectic team, as well as alone. The guiding principle of my life is "continuous improvement," and I firmly believe that it is never too late to acquire new knowledge and skills.

projects.title: Developement and validation of an incompressible CFD solver
projects.description: Project was the essential part of the course 'Computational Fluid Dynamics I'. Main goal of the work was to develop an incompressible 2D CFD solver and apply it to the lid-driven cavity flow. The CFD solver was programmed in MATLAB for any mesh resolution and initial/boundary conditions. Output of the program was a list of plots containing the distributions of different iso-vorticity lines, isobars, and streamlines within a lid cavity. Results were validated using the reference journal article written by Botella and Peyret (1997).

contributors.headline: PhD candidate at TU Delft with 4 years of engineering experience at Boeing supplier | Forbes 30 under 30
Lead Manufacturing Engineer (Product and Planning) at GKN Aerospace

projects.title: Optimization of a NACA 2411 at Cruise Conditions for UAVs
projects.description: Project was the essential part of the course 'Engineering Optimization'.  Main goal of the work was to optimize a NACA 2411 airfoil for a UAV wing in order to improve its range and fuel/power consumption. Aerodynamic optimization minimized the drag of the NACA 2411 at the given lift coefficient of 0.5 by modifying the airfoil shape. Value of the pitching moment was constrained by taking the NACA 2411 original pitching moment as the upper limit. Optimization was performed using XFOIL and MATLAB via a Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP).

profile_positions.description:
Pursuing a PhD degree in Computational Imaging group at the Faculty of Applied Sciences, Department of Imaging Physics. My work is in the field of dynamic light scattering optical coherence tomography (DLS-OCT) for measuring particle sizes and flow speeds in particle suspensions. This technology is primarily used for inline nanoparticle size measurements in pharmaceutical industry during the production of drugs and vaccines. Main tasks include:
- Optical design of a broadband OCT system (from UV to near IR).
- Performing time-sensitive and wavelength-dependent OCT measurements.
- Programming and running DLS-OCT simulations in python.
- Analyzing data, developing new models, quantifying uncertainty in measurements and simulations.
My research has already resulted in four publications and one patent application.
profile_positions.title: Doctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
I was working at the Engineering Department of ATC, a joint venture of JSC Partnership Fund of Georgia and Israeli Elbit Systems – Cyclone Ltd. that manufactures composite pats for the Boeing 787 Dreamliner. Tasks included: 
- Designing complete manufacturing process for composite parts, including preparation of manufacturing plans, process specification documents and bills of material. Designing different experiments for the laboratory. 
- Writing programs for the lay-up laser projectors and cutting machines. Designing the lay-up and CNC (computer numerical control) tools, models for NDI (non-destructive inspection) reference standards, caul plates and different holding fixtures.
- Following up production process, identifying and solving engineering-related issues for every part. 
- Improving engineering and production workflow by automatizing processes.
- Awarded the company prize ("Initiative for Process Optimization") for creating a software for automatic analysis of the autoclave cure cycle.
- Optimizing material usage in the lay-up process by numerical modelling in MATLAB. 
- Involved in the preparation of plans and reports for the company qualification activities. 
- Responsible for Part/Tool Thermal Profiling (PTTP) qualifications for all types of parts. 
- Responsible for preparation and execution of Boeing, NADCAP and ISO certifications. 
- Writing, reviewing and updating company’s engineering procedures, both in English and Georgian.
profile_positions.title: Engineering Team Lead

profile_positions.description:
I underwent a professional training at the Engineering Department of Elbit Systems - Cyclone. Tasks included: 
- Observing, studying, and participating in composites’ manufacturing process from the bottom up.
- Understanding the characteristics of different machines used in the manufacturing process. 
- Attending various lectures and seminars for deepening a theoretical knowledge in the field (including workshops for CATIA V5, ERP system, Composite Materials, etc.), performing on-job training. 
- Learning the specifications of manufacturing engineering, including the preparation of manufacturing plans, process specification documents and bills of material. 
- Studying writing programs for the lay-up laser projectors and cutting machines. Learning how to design the lay-up and CNC (computer numerical control) tools, models for NDI (non-destructive inspection) reference standards, caul plates and different holding fixtures using CATIA V5.
- Providing management with a feedback about the training program, suggesting possible improvements, assisting in planning and refining the material. 
- Actively taking part in the training program by giving different presentations to new trainees, such as “how to create programs for the lay-up laser projectors”, “thermomechanical analysis of thin composite laminates”, etc. 
- Learning how to write, review and update the company’s quality assurance and engineering procedures. 
- Working alongside Cyclone’s qualified engineers and managers for gaining experience.
profile_positions.title: Manufacturing Engineering Trainee

profile_positions.description:
For completing my master thesis at TU Delft, I worked as a researcher at the Department of Measurement Technology at the DLR Institute of Propulsion Technology under the project ‘OSIRIS’ (Optical Sensors for InstRuments In Flight Systems). Main goal was to investigate an optical flow measurement technique, Filtered Rayleigh Scattering (FRS), for measuring multiple parameters (temperature, density, velocity and pressure) in-flight and replacing the conventional measurement sensors onboard of airplanes. Tasks included:
- Literature review and analysis of the existing FRS techniques.
- Programming the end-to-end simulator for conceiving and investigating various FRS methods and setups.
- Developing a numerical scheme for predicting the measurement uncertainties for each FRS method.
- Optimizing setups and determining the best performing FRS method based on the expected measurement accuracies and certain design criteria from DLR. 
- Investigating optical setups in the lab for normalizing light power in the FRS experiments.  
- Validating the end-to-end simulator using the FRS experiments.
profile_positions.title: Scientific Worker

profile_positions.description:
I worked at the Department of Rotor Blade under the project ‘Smart blades’ for the design of innovative wind turbine rotor blades. The project aimed at reducing the blade bending moments using a bend-twist coupling by varying the fiber orientation angles. Tasks included:
- Extending MATLAB FEM beam cross section analysis tool to assess a fatigue damage of an arbitrary structure. The modified software can estimate the fatigue damage of a wind turbine blade for the given load cases.
- Deriving analytical solutions for the fatigue damage of simple cross sections and validating the extended code.
- Incorporating the software extension in a global optimization framework programmed in python. This allowed the fatigue analysis tool to become connected to the other software and usable in the wind turbine blade design process.
profile_positions.title: Intern

company.name: TU Delft Formula Student Racing Team

profile_positions.description:
I worked at the Chassis department of the Formula Student Team Delft which competes in FSAE Series world championship. Tasks included:
- Choosing the impact attenuator material and designing a crash nose for the car.
- Minimizing the crash nose weight and ensuring by calculations that FSAE requirements were met.
- Manufacturing different parts of the car using composite materials (rims, bodywork, etc.).
- Shortlisted as one of the potential drivers for the FSAE events.
profile_positions.title: Part-time engineer

profile_positions.description: I worked at the Department of Student Financial Services. My responsibility was to research external scholarships and funding possibilities for Georgian students.
profile_positions.title: Student Assistant

profile_positions.description:
I was the member of the Computational Materials Science research group of Prof. Dr.
Thomas Heine. I was investigating doped and alloyed metal oxide nanoparticles for the photocatalytic water splitting. My tasks included:
- Developing a C++ program for finding and filtering all possible doped structures.
- Preparing and passing files to the supercomputers for the quantum mechanical calculations.
- Modeling the available structures and determining the most optimal configurations.
profile_positions.title: Part-time Researcher

profile_positions.company: Fr. Lürssen Werft GmbH & Co. KG
profile_positions.description:
Lürssen is the world's largest manufacturer of luxury yachts based in Bremen, Germany. Shipyard also produces naval vessels for the member states of NATO. I worked in the area of acoustics and vibrations at the Department of Basic Design. My tasks and responsibilities included:
- Input, sort, and analysis of the ship acoustic data.
- Classifying yachts based on the room arrangement and propulsion systems.
- Physical and mathematical description of an airflow in the ventilation system.
- Conducting measurements on board using the noise level meter.
- Developing a VBA software for the ventilation noise level prediction.
- Comparing the noise level predictions with the measurements and validating the software.
- Designing and conducting the fire resistance experiments.
- Maintaining and improving the interactive sound presentation software.
profile_positions.title: Part-time Engineer

company.name: Fr. Lürssen Werft GmbH & Co. KG, Bremen, Germany

profile_positions.company: Fr. Lürssen Werft GmbH & Co. KG, Bremen, Germany
profile_positions.description: During my internship at Lürssen, I was responsible for developing an interactive sound presentation software in Java and MATLAB that would display the differences between the yacht noise levels, depending on the propulsion arrangements and positions on board. Using a calibrated sound system, software can reconstruct the authentic noise level from the different ship rooms. It also displays a third-octave band pressure levels for each yacht room. Screenshots from this program are shown below.
profile_positions.title: Intern

volunteer_experiences.description: I was a member of the teaching group responsible for giving classes to Georgia-Russian war refugee children. I was teaching different subjects to the refugee students, including the basics of physics, math, and programming.
